importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas attacks on Israel, which led to the abduction of hostages and initiated the ongoing hostage crisis and ceasefire negotiations.
The estimated date when Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage, was killed in captivity by Hamas during the October 7 attacks.
The signing date of the US-proposed ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, which mandated the return of deceased hostages within 72 hours.
The date on which the bodies of Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar were returned to Israel from Gaza, marking a significant development in the hostage recovery process.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe set by the US-proposed ceasefire agreement for Hamas to return all deceased hostages to Israel.

keyTakeAways: The body of Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage taken by Hamas during the October 7 attacks, was returned to Israel on October 22, 2025, marking a rare and significant recovery of a deceased hostage.
Tamir Adar, a 38-year-old farmer and educator from Kibbutz Nir Oz, died defending the kibbutz during the initial attacks and was later returned to Israel after being held in Gaza.
Hamas has returned 15 of the 28 deceased hostages as per the ceasefire agreement, but Israel believes Hamas may not be able to recover all remaining bodies due to the challenging conditions in Gaza.
An Israeli source indicated that one of the bodies returned by Hamas earlier did not belong to an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible misidentification or operational challenges.

US Vice President JD Vance expressed that while returning bodies is a priority, the process is complex and 'not going to happen overnight', emphasizing the difficulty of locating and recovering bodies buried under rubble.
The return of these bodies has deep emotional and symbolic significance for families and the broader Israeli public, who see it as a step toward justice, closure, and honoring the lives lost.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His return represents a major milestone in the recovery of hostages, symbolizing the return of the oldest victim and a personal triumph for the Zalmanovich family and the wider community.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His return underscores the broader effort to recover all deceased hostages and reflects the personal loss and grief felt by his family and the community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 22, 2025, the bodies of Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage taken by Hamas during the October 7, 2023 attacks, and Tamir Adar, a farmer and educator who died defending Kibbutz Nir Oz, were returned to Israel from Gaza. The Israeli Defense Forces confirmed their identities and the recovery process continued under the terms of a U.S.-proposed ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025. While Hamas has returned 15 of the 28 deceased hostages, Israel and the U.S. remain concerned about the difficulty of recovering all bodies, especially those buried under rubble or missing entirely. The return of these two bodies is significant both symbolically and emotionally, as it represents closure for families and underscores the ongoing challenges in resolving the hostage crisis. US Vice President JD Vance acknowledged the difficulty of the process, stating that recovery is not going to happen overnight, but emphasized the importance of continuing efforts to bring bodies home for proper burial.
title: Oldest Hostage Taken by Hamas Among Two Deceased Returned to Israel Tuesday
